name: Super Sanctum TD
description: Super Sanctum TD is a retro-styled Tower Defense game that focuses on strategy, customization and replayability. Build advanced mazes and construct powerful towers to prevent alien hordes from reaching the Core!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP (SP3), 7 or 8 Processor: 1 GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: DirectX-Compatible DirectX®: 9.0c Hard Drive: 100 MB Free Space Sound: DirectX-Compatible

reviews.review_text: Super Sanctum TD is typical towers defense game, nothing more, nothing less. Yes, this game looks on screenshots like 20 years old game which may be repulsive. I don't even know why I started to play this game, but for sure I didn't have any expectations. And I realised that I have 13 hours playtime. That was good time for sure. This game is well designed, difficulty level grows with every level, so it's not so hard to start but it's getting difficult after some time. But you will want to pass only one level, and next after that, and maybe next... And so on. Generally very well designed, polished and properly balanced piece of a game. It's really hard to find something as good in such a price. Good job.  VERDICT: If you're a fan of tower defence games, this is good one. Try it, you won't regret. If you have only few bucks and want to play for long hours, this is it!  Like this review? This game had a really tough rollout with lots of bugs and crashes, but even at its worst, it was loads of classic tower defense fun. Sanctum is know for putting a First Person twist on tower defense, and while this retro take comes with familiar tower mechanics and enviornments, it feels like a completely different experience, and a positive one. Outside of the traditional tower defense formula, you also get experience points and as you beat levels, you can earn perks to upgrade damage, enhance the economics of the game and boost your abilities.  As to the bugs, the devs have been working hard at improving the experience, and they seem to have the worst bugs whipped. They've also been tinkering with balance to create a tough but fair play experience. The fixes have been a little slow in coming, but I'm generally happy that they stuck it out and managed to get it fixed.  On Steam, this is my second favorite tower defense behind Defense Grid.

First off this game is a blast. It has fun retro graphics and an excellent level of difficulty for those of us that love tower defense games. There is a great combination of watching your towers tear apart enemy waves as well as hands on skills that you need to use when the going gets tough. It's fun to see the use of various Sanctum enemies and mechanics in a purely tower defense format. If you are a fan of either of the Sanctum games or are purely looking for a challenging tower defense game then this game is definitely for you. Great bang for the buck

Super Sanctum TD is a tower defense game that's fun and addictive while it lasts, but considering the large amount of unused space on the world map, seems unfinished - or maybe it was supposed to have DLC that never got made.  Anyway, each level has a Normal and Hard difficulty setting, but 'Hard' is rather hit or miss as far as challenge goes. The problem is that once you've played enough on Normal, you'll unlock a plethora of skills to make the Hard difficulty that in name only. However, some of the stages near the end, especially the one with the boss that replicates itself, will take a lot of planning and strategy if you're going for the 3-star achievements.  It often goes on sale for less than a dollar. If you like tower defense games and getting Steam achievements, it's an easy recommendation for that.  Rating: 3/5

Awesome little old school TD. Win missions to get exp, level up to unlock more towers and powers (basically abilities with no resource cost. Just cooldowns). Also has a skill tree.  Unlike most old school browser TD's, this is balanced, challenging, and constantly fun. My 'time played' is how long it took for me to beat the whole game on Normal, so it isn't very long (unless you plan on trying to beat it on hard afterwards).

I play this on my Dell Latitude E6500 laptop which has no graphics card and just 1gig of ram. It starts up fine and doesn't lag at all. Each tower can be upgraded three times. Some towers attack just ground, some just air, and some ground and air. All levels have a survival mode, and every level has a leaderboard.  There are upgrades that carry from level to level in the form of commander upgrades which can be reset at any time without penalty which lets you experiment with different tower specs and loadouts. There are also special spell-like abilities that you can employ such as a bomb that resets every 20seconds, croud control effects such as freezing, and temporary tower boosts.  There are strategy elements to how towers are placed, how abilities are used, and what your spec is, and how they compliment each other. There are lots of options to play with, and it is fun to experiment. It is not as deep of strategy as a larger game, but this is not meant to be that kind of game. A basic level can be completed in 10 minutes. In survival mode a level can last an hour easily. This game is very very accesible and easy to drop in and out of.  The difficulty escallates rather slowly, but with survival modes and leader boards you are ensured a challenge. That said I am past the first half of the game, and did so casually from my baby's hospital room. I got this title on sale for under $1, and it has been well worth it. Very happy with this game and purchase, and replayability is awesome.  For the price, depth of strategy, and replayability I give this a solid 7/10, and if you like tower defense it is a no-brainer to pick it up I believe.

Super Sanctum TD is a competently-designed, retro-flavored tower defense game that takes few risks and offers an appropriate degree of Fun. An endless horde of horrible space monstroids is pouring out of a weird invasion portal cabbage and it's up to you to place a variety of defensive turrets in the way to stop 'em! Along with your chain guns and flamethrowers and gauss rifles, you also have access to a variety of special abilities you can activate to blast those determined jerkfaces who manage to scrape their way past your gauntlet. As you play, you earn experience, unlocking new turrets and abilities. Level layout and wave composition are well-balanced, keeping up the challenge and often requiring multiple level attempts to achieve any sort of victory. And when all is said and done, you can go back for further challenges by attempting earlier levels on Hard Mode or Survival Mode.  Unfortunately, this game comes from the same people who made Sanctum, which was a delightfully innovative tower defense / FPS hybrid. Dropping all the innovative aspects of the game just makes this seems like an attempt at cashing in on the franchise's name, which, y'know, isn't terribly exciting to the fans; the lore was never terribly compelling to begin with, and this entry contributes nothing new on that front. If you're an avid tower defense enthusiast, sure, the game isn't bad, but you'd be better off playing the other games in the series or trying out a more polished, well-developed tower defense game like Sol Survivor.

On first glance, Super Sanctum TD seems like a very nice addition to the genre, but beware as the game is unbelievably hard even at normal difficulty forcing you to grind the same levels over and over until you get enough points to unlock new abilities/equipment. I'm not new to the TD genre but this game simply doesn't have mercy on its players; you have to optimize your maze layout to perfection and be very careful of selecting which towers to employ or there's no way you'll progress far beyond the training area. The 16-bit graphics look nice and serve their purpose, but the sound design is weak and rudimentary.  Generally speaking, the game is way too hard and demands a far bigger commitment than I'm willing to make for what is basically a 2D flash TD game. Could've been much better if the devs weren't so hard-core. But I guess even the TD genre has to have its masochistic version of IWBTG.  Score: 3/5
